Mechanisms of Antimicrobial Resistance

How are microbes adapting to the one of tools safeguarding our life, and why we could be in trouble

01 May 2025
Biomedicine
Molecular Biology

Cover image from Bacteria and Their Products (1903), by Sir German Sims Woodhead. It depicts a microscopy photograph of Anthrax bacilli extracted from a cow's spleen.

Who am I?

Hi, I am Giovanni, a ML engineer working on biomedical applications of machine learning and AI. Creating pipelines to manipulate data and train models takes up most of my normal workdays. You can read more about it in the About Me page.

I have research experience within the field of antibiotic resistance, and I find the topic both fascinating and horrifying. This post is meant as a note for me to have a compact summary of the main notions regarding how microbes gain resistance to antibiotics, and I hope you can find it useful too.

Note: in this post I will use somewhat interchangeably the terms antibiotic and antimicrobial for ease of discussion, but that is somewhat imprecise. The main difference is that an antibiotic targets bacteria, while an antimicrobial acts on a variety of microorganisms. So antibiotics are a subclass of antimicrobials, but that term is used much more commonly in colloquial speech, and I will do the same here.

Antimicrobial Resistance (AMR)

Antimicrobials (i.e. substances that kill or inhibit bacteria, parasites, fungi, and viruses) have been one of the most miraculous discoveries of the 20th century, saving millions of lives and substantially reducing the impact of infectious diseases.

Take a look, for example, at the dramatic effect of the introduction of sulfa drugs, just one single class of antibiotics:

Some decades were necessary to move from initial discovery to mass production, but once it happened the effects were dramatic, leading to the Antibiotic Golden Age between the 40s and the 60s. For a more detailed (and entertaining) overview of the history of antibiotics and antimicrobials, I refer to the excellent YouTube channel by Patrick Kelly, which does a fantastic job of exploring the human triumphs and shortcomings in this medical revolution.

Unfortunately, the marvelous benefits of this scientific treasure are now under threat: more and more, microbes are adapting to the substances we use to kill them, leading to increased risks of deadly infections.

Worringly,

a recent report [2] has estimated that AMR has claimed at least one million lives each year since 1990; forecasts estimate that between now and 2050 AMR infections will be directly responsible for 39 million deaths, as well as contributing to a broader 169 million deaths.

These catastrophic numbers reveal the scale of the problem and emphasize the need for additional research efforts in this field. This post does not aim to be a comprehensive exploration of the causes of AMR, or the policies that we should adopt to prevent the worsening of this issue, but rather a simplified explanation of the molecular mechanisms that microbes use to escape the effects of antimicrobials. Many excellent papers have been written on the topic (e.g. [3, 4, 5]), and they served as the basis for this post.

The molecular mechanisms of antimicrobials

Antibiotics and antimicrobials are often substances produced by natural organisms to kill or suppress competitors, giving them an advantage in a biological niche. Synthetic compounds (the earliest of which was salvarsan) recreate the same kind of effects on microorganisms. But how do they work? And consequently, how do bacteria and other microorganisms counteract them?

Generally speaking, antimicrobials break or slow down some biological processes that are crucial for the survival of the microbe. This could mean, for example, that a compound could prevent a bacterium from forming a cell wall or from producing RNA and proteins. Here you can see a summary of the main modes of actions for antibiotics:

So how do these stop working? Broadly speaking, microbes can act on either the antimicrobial substance or on the target of the drug.

Pathways of resistance

As mentioned, microbes can either do something about the antimicrobial drug, or they can render it ineffective by moving (figuratively) the target. Here is a visual overview of the main methods to achieve either of these outcomes.

When it comes to the antimicrobial drug, a microbe like a bacterium has the following options to counteract it directly:

  • Reduce the influx of the drug by making the membrane less permeable
  • Raise the rate at which the antimicrobial is expelled by upregulating efflux pumps
  • Modify and break the antimicrobial molecule with enzymes

The first two methods simply reduce the quantity of the drug below a critical threshold, while the last involves a more direct removal of the problematic substance.

Alternatively, each antimicrobial drug acts by influencing a specific target, for example by binding to the active site of certain proteins or by degrading other molecules. If the bacterium can influence this interaction, then the effect of a drug may be greatly diminished or even completely nullified. Some mechanisms through which this happens are:

  • Target protection, where certain proteins "shield" the antibiotic target
  • Target site modification, in which the shape of a binding site on the target is modified, in a way that prevents the antimicrobial from acting
  • Target bypass, a change in the internal biological processes such that the targeted molecule is no longer necessary

As a note, the brief summary that I gave may provide the feeling that there is some teleological drive within a bacterium to activate or create these mechanisms, but they are really the result of mutations paired with selective pressure, aided by contributing mechanisms such as horizontal gene transfer. The specific ways in which AMR arises and spreads are a fascinating topic of discussion, which I will leave for a separate post in the near future.

What do we do about this?

You may get the feeling that, given this broad understanding of the issue, we might be close to a solution, but unfortunately that is not the case. AMR is a complex problem, and facing it will require a combination of changes in policies, research into new drugs (and especially new classes of drugs), and synergistic therapies. I will cover some of these aspects in another separate post.

References

  1. Jayachandran, Seema, Adriana Lleras-Muney, and Kimberly V. Smith. "Modern medicine and the twentieth century decline in mortality: Evidence on the impact of sulfa drugs." American Economic Journal: Applied Economics 2.2 (2010): 118-146.

  2. Naghavi, Mohsen, et al. "Global burden of bacterial antimicrobial resistance 1990‚Äì2021: a systematic analysis with forecasts to 2050." The Lancet 404.10459 (2024): 1199-1226.

  3. Munita, Jose M., and Cesar A. Arias. "Mechanisms of antibiotic resistance." Virulence mechanisms of bacterial pathogens (2016): 481-511.

  4. Blair, Jessica MA, et al. "Molecular mechanisms of antibiotic resistance." Nature reviews microbiology 13.1 (2015): 42-51.

  5. Darby, Elizabeth M., et al. "Molecular mechanisms of antibiotic resistance revisited." Nature Reviews Microbiology 21.5 (2023): 280-295.
